title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act is titled the "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" and includes the establishment of the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a final map and boundary description for the scenic area, which will be available for public inspection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in the Chattahoochee National Forest, Georgia, covers 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a map and boundary description for the area. Management priorities include protecting scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and wildlife habitat. Recreation opportunities will also be provided, with management purposes taking precedence over general National Forest System laws and regulations. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years of the Act's enactment. No new roads can be built in the area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvesting is prohibited, except for fire control, insect/disease management, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary may engage in vegetation manipulation practices for maintenance of wildlife clearings and visual quality. Motorized travel is generally prohibited within the scenic area, but may be authorized for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed to maintain management purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to protect scenic quality and private lands. The scenic area will be administered to maintain water resources. The scenic area will be administered to maintain water quality and federally owned lands are withdrawn from mining activities. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AS WILDERNESS IN GEORGIA. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness areas, including additions to existing Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, Brasstown, Ellicott Rock, and Cohutta Wilderness areas. The Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch are new wilderness areas in Georgia totaling 3,343 acres. Final maps and boundary descriptions will be submitted to Congress, and the lands will be administered subject to existing rights. The Secretary shall administer the newly designated wilderness areas in Georgia in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section, with any references to the effective date of the Wilderness Act deemed to be the date of enactment of this Act. The State of Georgia retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest, and the Federal land designated as wilderness is withdrawn from certain uses. The Federal land designated as wilderness by this section is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral and geothermal leasing or mineral materials.
